captions.text: Hello Internet,

Recently YouTube invited me to California
for a conference with a bunch of really interesting

people. There were many talks and giant balloons
and much discussion of what the future of

education might look like -- which is no small
issue because how society raises the next

generation of scientists, doctors, and programmers
shapes the future of human civilization.

It was an amazing few days and, if you'll
tolerate my ramblings, I'd like to share some

of my thoughts on this as someone who's worked
as an educator both in and out of schools.

So this is how schools have pretty much always
looked: a guy in the front who knows all the

things and students who don't so the guy tells
them.

But a teacher explains things at the right
pace for maybe *one* student in the room during

a lesson. Everyone else is either bored because
they already understand the material or lost

because they're missing knowledge they should
already have.

But, at the end of the lesson, regardless
of student understanding, the circeirculem
marches rentlessly on.

And whether the teachers use a blackboard,
whiteboard or smart board and whether students

use tables, or paper, or tablets (again) this
system really isn't any different -- it's

just technology doing the same thing in a
shiner way.

But the Internet is different and behind the
scenes something interesting is happening
that hints at the shape of things to come.

In a perfect school, each student would have
a personal tutor, like Aristotle to Alexander
the great.

But if your education policy is 'Aristotle
for everyone' then there are three big problems
with this:

1st) There aren't enough humans on Earth to
individually tutor every child, and even if

there were it would be horrifically expensive
and even if neither manpower nor money was

a problem not everyone is as good a tutor
as Aristotle.

But technology is solving these problems:
starting with number 1:

For who needs humans when the Internet can
teach you all the things?
Want to learn calculus: get started.

Need an AP biology course? Go watch this one
along with hundreds of thousands of other
students.

The Internet massively multiplies the audience
of potential teachers and solves the manpower
problem.

But isn't cheerleading the Internet the same
thing I was complaining about before: new

tech doing old things just with more shiny?
After all if you were a pre-Internet child,

with bookish inclinations, there's *always*
been a place to teach you all the things.

And people thought that radio and TV were
going to revolutionize education by giving

teachers huge audiences, but here we still
are.

These are good points but Internet also solves
the cost problem in a way that Radio and TV
never could.

Real shows are expensive to make and even
the best of educational TV often gets pushed

aside for dumber, more popular stuff that,
not coincidently, is also more profitable.
This is known as the History Channel Effect.

But the cost to access to the Internet is
only going down, as is the cost to make stuff
for the Internet.

Which is why a guy with some paper and a marker
in his bedroom can pull in a million views

a month at essentially zero cost and doesn't
have to worry about competition from stuff
like this.

So the Internet solves problems one and two,
but educational videos still aren't personalized

to students and that leaves YouTube still
as a library of video, not a tutor like Aristotle.

But you can build on top of YouTube and what
I see coming is this: Digital Aristotle for
everyone.

A computer program that tutors students individually,
by pulling from a library of videos like YouTube,

a program that tests students on what they
know and, more importantly, adapts to the

way they learn over time by comparing the
effectiveness of different videos and different

tests to discover scientifically, what works
best.

This isn't a fantasy, there are people building
parts of this right now (even if Digital Aristotle

isn't their explicit goal). And one of these
places is The Khan Academy which is more than

just Sal's soothing voice. If this does not
blow your mind, you have no emotion. Behind

the website is incredibly complicated software
testing everything about student learning:

the effectiveness of different videos, different
tests, and different ways of asking questions.

And while it may seem primitive now, technology
only gets better, faster. When Digital Aristotle

arrives it will be cheaper, less labor intensive
and better than human teachers ever could
be.

I often hear the argument that Digital Aristotle,
or something like it, will free teachers to

float around the classroom helping kids works
on interesting projects -- and while that

might happen in the near-term, I don't think
that's the long-term reality.

For what happens when Digital Aristotle truly
knows students better than the teacher? When,

for every topic of human endeavor, it's able
to take the best and brightest kids farther

down the path of knowledge than their teachers
ever could?

I doubt that schools will go away -- after
all they aren't just about learning but are

also freeing parents to work in the economy
while their feral children are turned into

civilized adults -- but schools will be radically
different and there will be far fewer teachers
working in them doing far less.

And while that's not great news for teachers,
it's awesome news for students and society.

Right now, if you're a student doing poorly
school moves on without you and if you're
doing well, school holds you back.

In the future, I see every human using a Digital
Aristotle for their whole life, a tutor personalized

to them, teaching them exactly what they need
to learn when they're best ready for it and

when that comes, we'll have both a better
educational system and a better society.

I want to thank YouTube EDU and the people
who ran it for bringing me out to California

to meet up with these awesome people. I had
more interesting conversations over the space

of a few days than I normally get to have
over the space of a few months.

If you want to see what the best of education
looks like right now, go check out their channels

and if you want to hear more on this topic,
I've also put together a playlist of talks
on this topic I hope you like.

title: Digital Aristotle: Thoughts on the Future of Education

comments.text:
Ok, I have to ask a question: Is the narrator a digitized voice from a 
program, or is he an actual human who is merely speaking exceptionally 
precise? Seriously, I need to know because it pretty much freaks me out. ﻿
comments.author: bluestudio67

comments.text: Digital Indoctrination﻿
comments.author: Leonard Dawson

comments.text:
The importance of a teach is not of the cirriculum, but of the personal 
interaction between the studemts and the teacher. There is a reason why 
people who are self taught or home schooled normally fail in society. It is 
that the social skills you learn in school will carry you farther in life 
than anything you learn there. You can always learn on your own, as most of 
us are doing, but teachers will forever be important.﻿
comments.author: Adam Hamrick

comments.text:
I think this is great, but students need humans and human interaction, you 
need a human teacher and fellow students to become social and learn more 
about other peoples values and beliefs. Because video classes on Muslim 
theology might teach you what they tend to believe, but not every Muslim 
follows that particular doctrine. but just implementing this in classes, 
having supervising teachers who can double as psycologists over a smaller 
group of childeren (Say a class of 10-15) might be the future of Education.﻿
comments.author: Sebas Manders

comments.text:
A program can probably provide you with knowledge. It could customize the 
information that you are interested in and provide you with more of this, 
but schools don't exist for this or actually should not exist for this. 
Schools should teach children more important things, like social skills 
through working in teams with "live" people, respect for the other people, 
greater values like freedom, peace, democracy through, for example, solving 
issues among their team members and, of course the mental tools, like 
critical thinking, to process all the information that they get. Working 
with other people, researching your surroundings together, teaches also 
self awareness. You are able to define yourself, what you want and what you 
want from other people, forces you to express you thoughts and your 
feelings and learn the results of your actions, how you affect other people.
These things can't be taught by a video, or any fancy interactive or 
multi-user technology, these things are taught through experience through 
living in the real world. Don't get me wrong, technology can be a part of 
this kind of school, where teachers and students cooperate and learn 
simultaneously how to live in a society.
+CGP Grey  I think that in this video, you think of school just as a 
provider of knowledge, which is not or it shouldn't be, for example in 
Finland is not. Definitely, humans are social beings and need more than a 
customised provider of knowledge.﻿
comments.author: Fotis F

comments.text:
Education has taken a major step back wards due to how a student's 
educational progress is measured. It's no longer measured by application of 
knowledge ( ie; and hands on demonstration of the use of the knowledge in 
question.) It seems to always be handled in paperwork witch leads to people 
being better at memorization and regurgitation of knowledge rather than the 
application and significance of it.﻿

comments.author: Gabrielle Delacour (LeviosaNight)

comments.text:
I'm not a gaming enthusiast but I do see great potential for games to teach 
students and keep their attention. With the use of virtual reality learning 
could become very interactive and engaging. Imagine being given a 10 min 
video to watch and your homework would to go play a game.

 As an example imagine you have to create your own world for geography, you 
get given a blank grass plane and, much like age of empires/ dinopark, you 
can drop a mountain in the map. If you want to unlock storm clouds you have 
to watch the storm cloud video and answer a few short questions. If you 
want to add animals you can join a biology coarse and then unlock the 
animal kingdom by learning about it. This idea can be carried over to other 
subjects like maths and science where if you want to play the racing game 
you can learn how the engine works. This is a very simple illustration but 
the point I want to bring across is that people love being creative, not 
just arts and craft but also creative problem solving, and if you have to 
learn about things before you have access to them in the virtual reality 
you can see how things work immediately and not have to see how the example 
your teaches gives is applicable to whatever it is you're trying to do. 

I'll agree that at first the lion and zebra video will be watched and kids 
will want to make things kill each other/ burn/ break but thats the whole 
point. They will see the implications of their choices and with time will 
grow bored of that. The possibilities for constructive creativity are 
endless where as destructive and violent choices will generally have the 
same result. 

We may just be able to teach kids to think about the far reaching 
consequences of their choices long before they appear in the real world.﻿

classroom education? Or the unique things that school offers them like

comments.author: Laurence Gingell

comments.text:
I appreciate what you say here, but I also disagree about teachers not 
knowing their students as well as the Aristotle program. Sure, the program 
may know the student better in an academic way, but understanding the 
socioeconomic status or the cultural background of a student and using 
those to teach students about being active in their communities are things 
I don't see machines being able to adapt to any time soon (and I understand 
that some schools don't teach this but it's definitely a way I plan to 
teach my students about applying the things they learn in my classroom).

And even so, I still don't think that the machine would do this well 
because it is important that people be exposed to things that make them 
question the world around them. They need to be exposed to things they can 
relate to directly and they need to be exposed to things that are similar 
but require a little more abstract thinking in order to make the connection 
(sorry, I'm coming from a humanities perspective as I am an Language Arts 
teacher who is becoming increasingly frustrated at how little attention and 
importance people are placing upon "soft" subjects like mine). I just don't 
see how an algorithm could do something like this, like exposing a student 
to something they can relate to and get them familiar with one way of 
thinking and then start turning that on its head or exposing the biases 
behind that way of thinking.

This program could definitely narrow the achievement gap, but schools are 
not just day care centers... they also provide a space for social growth 
and a space to practice the things that their personal tutor is working 
with them on by providing the materials necessary to put the skills to work 
(for example, if a student was learning how to sew, they would need a 
needle and thread or a sewing machine to practice with).

Schools will need to exist in order to simply provide access to the 
technology that would be necessary for a student to have this personal 
tutor, because access to the internet may be getting cheaper but minimum 
wage is still pretty damn low, so poor families are still not likely to own 
or have regular access to a computer. For the same reason public libraries 
exist, public schools exist in order to give everyone "equal" access to a 
"good" education. As things currently stand, it is glaringly obvious that 
not all schools are created equal, but I definitely believe that we are 
heading in a direction for a stronger and fairer system of education and 
technology is certainly one of the reasons why that's happening. :)﻿
comments.author: Katie Griggs

comments.author: Ammar Abotouk

comments.text:
+CGP Grey Teacher and Tutor here (with some software design experience) .

I know with certainty that students (many students have expressed this to 
me) hate it when their teachers pull videos off of youtube rather than 
giving lectures. Kids drift more, not less in these situations. Part of the 
problem is that kids don't control the videos and they are not customized 
to them, but another big element of this is that students are genetically 
programmed to pay attention to PEOPLE that are paying attention to them.

On top of that, good teachers or tutors are constantly doing things like 
monitoring the students body language, health, environmental factors, 
social relationships, tone of voice and on... No one has yet designed a 
piece of software that comes even close to this level of sophistication. We 
may routinely now process terabytes of data vs the kilobystes we did when i 
was a kid, but out algorithms are not growing in sophistication and 
subtlety by moore's law, they are barely smarter than they were 30 years 
ago.

Siri is not Aristotle and good luck getting educational pundits to come 
together and produce something half as what apple can do.﻿
comments.author: michalchik

comments.text:
+michalchik Just to clarify this is in the UK here. Students are divided 
into sets 1-6. 1 being the highest, and 6 being the lowest. I am set 2 for 
English and Maths, and set 1 for everything else. This is the higher of the 
scale but not exactly substantial. Also bear in mind that I am not by any 
sense of the imagination the best in my classes. I get about average grades 
for my sets.

What exactly would you classify as "average"? Set three? Because then 
you're excluding 5/6 of the year. I am a perfectly normal student, with no 
disabilities or learning difficulties. I don't quite understand what you 
mean by "substantially above average".
comments.author: Laurence Gingell

comments.text:
I don't understand your answer to 1. Are you saying your placement is in 
the highest or second highest classes? In that case your are subtsantially 
above average in academic performance and probably maturity.

The teaching style in the humanities are somewhat different since it is 
more about story telling even when it involves real events.
comments.author: michalchik

comments.text:
1. Yes. Sets two to one for all of my subjects (i.e. highest to second 
highest classes).

2. We do watch videos in the classroom quite often. Mostly we do it in the 
humanities (R.E., History, Geography, and ICT), and they're much better 
than listening to a teacher blabber on. We watch videos when the teachers 
want to give us information to copy down, or when they want to measure our 
understanding of the subject covered in the video by asking us questions. 

What would be great is if this "Internet Aristotle" gave a video to watch, 
or an article or example to read, analyse our understanding of the subject, 
and then devise or issue a series of exercises to practice with.
comments.author: Laurence Gingell

comments.text:
+Laurence Gingell Great! So do I. But,

1) Are you a typical normal average student?
2) Is most of the watching you do based on teachers choices they make you 
watch instead of lectures, collaborative work and question and answer 
periods, or do you watch them based on your interest and needs to solve 
problems, on your schedule, stopping and rewinding as you please?

My complaint is not that videos can't aid education, it is that they fail 
as a replacement for teacher led classroom discussion, lecture and 
activities.
comments.author: michalchik

comments.text:
+michalchik As a current student I disagree with everything you say. I 
happily watch and learn things from Youtube videos all the time. I can 
learn more from Crash Coruse, CGP Grey, and Vsauce in a day than I do at 
school in a week. Youtube videos are fun, entertaining, and most 
importantly, visual and engaging. What makes you think people are the same?

comments.author: Dylan O'Hara

comments.text:
+Skadu Skitai You make a good point that there are better ways of using 
them, but i think my point still stands. Students instinctively need to 
feel that someone is paying attention to them to feel focused. That is just 
how we are wired to work.
comments.author: michalchik

comments.text:
Using Youtube lectures that way is completely missing the point. The point 
with youtube lectures is that you personally digest them at your own 
leisure. An unfamiliar term is used? You can pause the video and look up a 
dictionary. Some concept seems unclear? You can revisit the video 
explanation or pause and go to wikipedia or something for illumination. 
It's boring and you are really unfocused today? You can watch the video 
tomorrow. You are captivated with the subject and everything is crystal 
clear? Great here's the next lecture for you. E.t.c. This personal 
flexibility is the point of youtube lectures and indeed the whole concept 
of digital tutoring. 

Used correctly I don't think it would replace the need for teachers though. 
On the contrary it requires a much more personal interaction with every 
student than traditional teaching.
comments.author: Skadu Skitai

comments.author: Joshua Games (Satyr Games)

comments.text:
Is it just me, or is the prospect that there could be a computer program 
that knows me and could teach me better than any human ever could 
incredibly scary? It's not so much the fact that a computer could teach me, 
and people like me better than a human that scares me, but that one could 
KNOW me, and empathize with me, think how I, a human thinks. That 
hypothetical computer is starting to sound quite a bit like a human, and if 
we can make machines that are effectively humans, replicating our ability 
to empathize and understand in order to teach, what's stopping someone 
making a robot who can feel emotions, not just replicate them. What if that 
computer can make others? What if it, and all of its children think that 
humans got it wrong? What if they decide to start a war? I realize I am 
jumping to quite a few conclusions and making a lot of assumptions, but 
those are some of my greatest fears.﻿
comments.author: Seth Jones

comments.text:

of learning...﻿

comments.text:
Wait, isn't Aristotle always wrong?

comments.author: Isaac Mark

comments.text:
Love your videos. On this one, am wondering if there were any experts from 
the field of education research at the tech ed gathering you attended. Two 
issues. 1) Students do not learn particularly well through a single 
modality, whether it's lecture (as alluded to), or project-based inquiry. 
2) Most students, most of the time, learn most effectively through social 
constructivism, whereby peers assist one another.﻿
comments.author: bryander

comments.text:
I am not saying you are definitely wrong, but please be careful and cite! 
Also, good teachers make your videos available and encourage our students 
to consume your media... and I am not saying teachers would stop bc of this 
video... but you are creating some problems with students misunderstanding 
this and putting less trust on their teachers.

I would like MUCH more data than you espousing the tech fallacy explained 
in "Voodoo Science". You are putting the nail on the coffin for teachers 
without any real backing.

I 100% agree with you with the role of computers and software, but having a 
teacher per 20 to 30 students is essential for a holistic delivery of 
education.

All of this will hopefully free up time for teachers to walk around the 
class to tutor individually, to assess, to report, and to inspire.﻿
comments.author: eipooqie

comments.text:
Is there anywhere I can find more information about the conference you 
mentioned? I want to see if this is the prevailing view among attendees 
particularly.

motivation to learn, and people will have a much better education for a 
better world. ﻿

comments.text: Awesome !﻿
comments.author: Sir Roger Oxford

comments.text:
i don't think it would work. not the the technology wouldn't be beneficial, 
but it will be manipulated, and pulling on a large pool of what's available 
might not be the best method for teaching anyone anything. a student who 
needs help with math might not understand a specific part of the math 
they're being taught. they explain this to DA, which finds them a video, or 
searches its reference pool and comes up with what it believes to be the 
right response, but is never able to empathize with the student in a way as 
to both understand AND present the information so that the student 
comprehends it. that will always be the shortcoming of technology in the 
classroom. the other will be the inequality of rich vs. poor in education, 
which has and will always play itself out in human history. minorities 
right now for example are at a disadvantage as technology increases in the 
classroom due to the income gap, which means that as technology becomes a 
more powerful tool inside and outside of the classroom, they're left 
further and further behind. trying to keep them all on level footing with 
legislation is also failing every student. unless humans turn over all 
reigns of education to computers, which they cannot and won't, nothing will 
change. ﻿
comments.author: L The Detective

comments.text:
I am a high-school freshman at an alternative school with teachers that do 
all they can to let students work at their own pace and learn what they 
need and want when they can. I'm enrolled in a pre-caculus course, 
senior/junior level Spanish, and even in my "normal" classes can go much 
further than my classmates should I choose. While the digital Aristotle 
idea is brilliant and wonderful and (in my opinion) needs to be 
implemented, it should also be this kind of school that remains, with human 
tutors alongside the electronic ones who really care more about the 
students' learning than their own paycheck; something else I've found to 
hinder the educational process tremendously.﻿
comments.author: Tröggâçom Càctüs

comments.text:
Most of the top comments here oppose this idea and I'd like to address the 
core ideas of some of their arguments:
1) "Computers and numbers could never teach as well as a real teacher 
could" Although computers aren't going to be as understanding and emotional 
as a real teacher, I would like you to think about this. The point of the 
teacher is not to understand the student, the point of the teacher is to 
teach. Cgp Grey is totally right when he says that the teacher in a 
classroom full of students cannot teach all the students individually as 
well as a computer personalized to each students could. Most of the 
students fall behind, and some are too far ahead to learn everything, and a 
small fraction is actually learning at a good pace. As we've seen for 
decades teachers can't teach everyone the way they need to be taught to 
learn the most
2) "A computer cannot teach language" Your forgetting that computers do 
teach language. Although they are just as bad as public school a whole lot 
of students already take digital classes and learn from them, from 
everything from language to programming to math digital classes do help 
people learn(although what Cgp is suggesting here would be way better then 
the digital classes we have today)
3) "A computer cannot teach discipline" It is not the computers job to 
teach discipline its the parents job, and you have to remember that large 
amounts of discipline are required in normal schools today, but if everyone 
had a digital Aristotle and did school at home while some discipline is 
needed to keep the student on course there isn't nearly as much involved 
and to some extent computers can teach discipline even if they aren't as 
good as teachers
4) "I wouldn't want me or my children to be taught by a mindless robot 
monster" This program is not aimed to be a mindless robot monster. Modern 
TV and video games often show computers like this but remember all your 
social media including the one that's allowing you to comment on this video 
right now is run by "Mindless Digital Monsters" and you don't care. Modern 
programming isn't some mindless digital monster droning something into your 
brain. You must have noticed that modern social media adapts to your tastes 
and sees what you like, well an educational tool like this could do that 
too.
5) Throw as many arguments as you want at this, but step back and look at 
our modern educational system. Its horrible, broken in almost every way and 
its only ideas like digital Aristotle that can change that.

I could go on and on with this but I've made this so long that not many 
people will bother to read this already, but I am in full support in all or 
most of the things mentioned in this video! I am one of those students that 
often finds classes boring because I'm ahead, and you really really do feel 
like your being held back.﻿
comments.author: Gwendolyn Peterson

 nothing to say?

in schools. You are implying that you are smarter than all the history  
teachers all the way from when this theory was put in the history books. 
Sorry but that is very arrogant of you. Making statements like that will 
not make the internet a better place.  Thanks
comments.author: Chris Boris

comments.text:
Perhaps, Chris, you should seek further education on the Internet for 
yourself. I will only mention it (because I understand how offended people 
become when some attempts to correct their grammar), but your lack of 
attention to detail, if any at all, makes it very difficult to understand 
your argument. It hurts to read what you wrote, not to mention difficult to 
follow.
Also, it is a very common misconception that people of earlier times 
believed that the earth was flat. This is an argument mainly construed 
around the time of Chris Columbus; most also believed that the earth was 
round. The flat theory is preposterous.
Lastly, how you come out calling CGP an "asshole" reflects more on you than 
him. If you were to make valid points based on valid facts, I, with almost 
everyone else, wouldn't consider you to be a grade schooler smashing keys 
on your keyboard. Please be more considerate before you post, along with 
putting in even the slightest bit of thought (which may be very difficult 
for you). This is the only way to make the Internet a better place.
Thanks

comments.author: azrael300s

comments.text:
This video is stupid. You're saying in a classroom that only one person 
understands what is going on and everyone else is either too slow to 
understand it or too fast. In a classroom, the kids participate and ask 
questions and talk to eachother and stuff. They all learn together and the 
teacher doesn't teach stuff that is too hard for kids to understand. 
Everyone can learn math or english or science. It's not that hard. And once 
you get to high school, you pick your own classes so kids can choose a 
class where the learning is slower and more in detail (like Life Science or 
Earth Science) or they can take the harder but better path (Biology, 
Chemistry, etc). Then in high school, kids with like minds come together 
and learn from teachers that do an amazing job with answering questions, 
explaining stuff, and doing activities. This "Digital Aristotle" bullcrap 
will not only never work, but is ridiculous to think it will replace 
teachers and classrooms. Schools are better for learning courses than 
trying to learn everything yourself.﻿

comments.author: Clinton Sam

comments.text:
I teach language. That's what I do. Plus, they pay me $50 an hour to do it 
and there aren't any free slots open in my schedule so I must be doing it 
right. Left the schools and have been doing it on my own for the past 6 
years. Before that I taught in private schools for just 4 years. Let's just 
say I am really damn good at what I do. And as far as neural networks go, 
funny how the children think they know everything and everyone else is just 
stupid. Yea, I was a child too once. You're wet behind the ears kids. You 
don't know what you're talking about. You have no life experience. You have 
a little bit of knowledge but you're still stupid.
comments.author: Clinton Sam

comments.text:
+Clinton Sam If you think computers cannot do what you think you cannot do 
ie teach languages, let me introduce you to neural networks. They already 
exist and have existed ever since the 1980's but the hardware wasn't good 
enough. Already, neural nets of about 1 million simulated neurons are able 
to recognize human speech, patterns in photos, replicate human speech, 
learn very human skills that a programmer cannot think of a way of solving 
it (the stock market for example) and all of these things already exist. 
The hardware is good enough for it, and is getting better. Soon, a mobile 
phone will be able to simulate billions or even trillions of simulated 
neurons already taught to do things.


Links to reasurch papers about nural networks


http://www.doc.ic.ac.uk/~nd/surprise_96/journal/vol4/cs11/report.html

http://www.willamette.edu/~gorr/classes/cs449/intro.html



Note, if you do read the stuff these links provide, there is heavy 
mathematics behind it so you may need to find out what this stuff means as 
you read it. Google is your friend.


And believe it or not, this is the slow method. There already exists 
methods that are faster than this that already do what you say. Do this 
research for yourself and think outside the box. This tech exists, now we 
wait for the hardware.

go to school i log in then because all the stupid kids are not there i can

know all the things after my 30 minutes of school (on a good day) to do all 
my 5 classes i then do 5 minutes of Duolingo for French I go to YouTube and 
watch educational videos, become smarter than all my friends and become the

because of the yearly placement tests to see if you should be held back, go 
to the next grade, skip a grade, or even more. They don't need a lot of 
teachers my math teacher has around 100 students, while some classes take
